SENT.plain: Incidence of spinal neurocysticercosis (NCC) is rare
Isolated spinal NCC is still rarer

We present here a case report where a young lady presented with all the clinical features of pseudotumor cerebri (PTC), where medical treatment for PTC failed and the presence of cysticercous in spinal canal was detected only on the operation table, while doing a lumbo-peritoneal shunt (LP shunt) to save her vision
Diagnosis could be confirmed only after the histopathology report was received
She did not have any direct evidence of spinal involvement, thereby eluding correct diagnosis
In English literature, we could not find any report of isolated and silent spinal NCC associated with PTC
In addition, we could not find any report of recovery of cysticercous larva through the Touhey's needle injury, although this was an incidental finding
In endemic areas, isolated spinal NCC should be suspected in patients presenting with PTC
